item.title: U.S. Reveals Death Toll From Airstrikes Outside War Zones
item.media:description: President Obama in the Oval Office of the White House in on Friday.
item.description: About 64 to 116 civilians and about 2,500 members of terrorist groups have died in American airstrikes, the Obama administration says, hundreds lower than independent estimates.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE and SCOTT SHANE
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Austria’s Highest Court Orders Repeat of Presidential Runoff
item.media:description: Norbert Hofer of the Freedom Party, left, and Alexander Van der Bellen, a former leader of the Green Party. Mr. Hofer lost to Mr. Van der Bellen in a May 22 vote.
item.description: A new presidential election in Austria could well serve as a referendum on the central tenets, roles and responsibilities of the European Union.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE and JAMES KANTER

item.title: No Charisma, No Glamour: Michael Gove Makes His Case to Lead Britain
item.description: The British justice secretary, one of the leaders of the Leave campaign, argued that he best represented the mood of the party and the country.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: German Sentenced to 14 Years for Stabbing Mayoral Candidate in Cologne
item.media:description: Henriette Reker campaigning for the mayoral election in Cologne, Germany, on Oct. 16, a day before she was stabbed. A man, identified only as Frank S., was found guilty on Friday of attempted murder.
item.media:credit: Oliver Berg/DPA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Judge Barbara Havliza said the attack at a campaign rally for Henriette Reker was an attempt “to create a climate of fear” at a time of large migration into the country.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: ISIS Claims Responsibility for Dhaka Attack and Hostage Standoff
item.media:description: Security personnel near a restaurant that was attacked by gunmen on Friday in Dhaka, Bangladesh.
item.description: Two police officers were killed in the Bangladesh capital, Dhaka, during a standoff at a restaurant in a popular expatriate neighborhood.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK, GEETA ANAND and RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Taking Down Politicians for Decades, and Rising in India’s Government
item.media:description: “My critics began saying I was a chauvinist, nationalist, mad nationalist.” SUBRAMANIAN SWAMY
item.description: Subramanian Swamy is arguably the most vicious infighter in the country’s politics, but the question is whether the prime minister can keep him on a tight enough leash.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND

item.title: Citing Safety, Bookseller Pulls Out of Hong Kong Pro-Democracy March
item.media:description: Lam Wing-kee. The bookstore where he worked in Hong Kong sold gossipy books about China’s leadership.
item.description: Lam Wing-kee had indicated that he had been followed over the previous two days by people he did not recognize, an official said.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Israel Imposes Restrictions on Palestinians in West Bank After Attacks
item.media:description: Israeli security forces investigated after an attack on a family driving near Hebron on Friday.
item.description: Israel said that it would prevent all Palestinian movement in the southern West Bank and withhold some crucial tax revenues from the Palestinian Authority.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID and SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Faulting Both Israelis and Palestinians, Report Aims to Revive Peace Talks
item.media:description: Yishuv Hadaat, a Jewish settlement outpost in the West Bank, in May.
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.description: The Middle East Quartet urged Israel to change its settlement policies and Palestinian groups to stop glorifying attacks.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: 3 Kenyans Last Seen at Police Station Are Found in a River
item.media:description: Lawyers rallied at Kenya’s Supreme Court in Nairobi on Wednesday to press the government’s investigation into the disappearance of three men — a lawyer, a client and a taxi driver.
item.description: The bodies of a lawyer, his last known client and a taxi driver were discovered after their disappearance last week unsettled human rights activists.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Refugees Encounter a Foreign Word: Welcome
item.description: How Canadian hockey moms, poker buddies and neighbors are adopting Syrians, a family at a time.
item.dc:creator: JODI KANTOR and CATRIN EINHORN

item.title: Reaction to Canada’s Warm Welcome for Syrian Refugees
item.description: Responses to a Times article on Canadians’ acceptance of refugee families ranged from “beautiful” to “a ticking time bomb.” What do you think?
item.dc:creator: ARI ISAACMAN BEVACQUA

item.title: Britons Put Rancor Aside to Commemorate the Battle of the Somme
item.media:description: Young people placed wreaths on graves at the Commonwealth cemetery in Thiepval, France, to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the the Battle of the Somme in World War I.
item.description: The nation turned away from discord over the vote to leave the European Union to mark the 100th anniversary of the bloody World War I battle.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Mosha, Thai Elephant Wounded by Land Mine, Gets New Prosthetic Limb
item.media:description: Mosha had her new prosthetic leg fitted in Lampang, Thailand, on Wednesday.
item.description: She is one of more than a dozen elephants who have been hurt near the border with Myanmar, where rebels have been fighting for decades.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK
item.category: Friends of the Asian Elephant Foundation

item.title: Chinese Court Postpones Trial of Activist, Angering Supporters
item.media:description: Chen Yunfei, an artist and activist, has been charged with “picking quarrels and provoking trouble,” a catchall crime that the Chinese authorities have used frequently in recent years to silence dissent.
item.description: The court did not give the artist and liberal political activist, Chen Yunfei, a new date for the trial or explain the delay, his lawyer said.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: ‘Brexit’ Briefing: Battle of the Somme; Tories Step Up as Boris Johnson Exits
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain attended an evening service in London to honor the centenary of the Battle of the Somme on Thursday.
item.media:credit: British Ministry of Defence/European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: The political crisis was temporarily set aside as leaders commemorated the Battle of the Somme, but candidates for prime minister are laying groundwork.
item.dc:creator: PRASHANT S. RAO

item.title: Hindu Priest in Bangladesh Is Hacked to Death
item.description: The priest is the fourth Hindu to be targeted in the last month in more than three years of similar killings by Islamist militants.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and GEETA ANAND
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Sinosphere: Taiwan Navy Accidentally Fires Antiship Missile, Killing Fisherman
item.description: The supersonic missile, which was set off during a training exercise, hit a fishing boat, killing its captain and injuring three crew members.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: U.N. Envoy Says Israeli Settlements ‘Undermine’ Peace Talks
item.media:description: Nickolay E. Mladenov, the United Nations Special Coordinator for the Middle East Peace Process, in Gaza City in February.
item.description: The comments offered a glimpse into a long-awaited, carefully negotiated report that is intended to help revive the peace process that collapsed more than two years ago.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Memo From London: Luck Runs Out for a Leader of ‘Brexit’ Campaign
item.media:description: Mr. Johnson prepared to speak at a Brexit campaign event at York Racecourse in York, England, in April.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: Boris Johnson, the chronically disheveled former mayor of London, was done in by his own hubris and lack of preparation in the face of the Brexit result.
item.dc:creator: SARAH LYALL

item.title: Syrians Stranded at Jordan’s Border Struggled to Survive. Then the Water Stopped.
item.media:description: Syrian refugees gathering for water last week at the Rukban refugee camp near Jordan’s northeastern border with Syria.
item.description: Since a suicide bomber killed seven Jordanian security officials more than a week ago, some 60,000 refugees have not had access to food or medicine.
item.dc:creator: RANA F. SWEIS and SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: U.N. Panel Moves to Curb Bias Against L.G.B.T. People
item.description: The Human Rights Council, over the objections of Muslim and Arab nations, approved measures to strengthen protections for gay, bisexual and transgender people.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: A Remark on Israel by Jeremy Corbyn Incites Outrage in Britain and Abroad
item.media:description: Jeremy Corbyn, the leader of Britain’s Labour Party, spoke Thursday in London at the public introduction of a report on anti-Semitism within the party.
item.description: Speaking at an event designed to address accusations of anti-Semitism in his Labour Party, Mr. Corbyn made a comment that was initially interpreted as comparing Israel to the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: ISIS Claims Killing of Coptic Christian Minister in Sinai
item.description: Father Rafael Moussa, 46, a Coptic Orthodox minister, was shot outside a car repair shop in one of several attacks since 2013 on Coptic Christians.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Italian Navy Recovers Ship Containing at Least 300 Migrants’ Bodies
item.media:description: The migrant ship that sank in 2015 being recovered from the Mediterranean Sea by the Italian Navy on Tuesday.
item.description: It is still unclear how many people died in the April 2015 shipwreck, which helped galvanize efforts to rescue people fleeing across the Mediterranean to Europe.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Russia Fires Dozens of Military Officers in Baltic Region
item.media:description: Vice Admiral Viktor Kravchuk, one of the officers whose firings were announced on Wednesday.
item.description: Citing “dereliction of duty” and distortion of “the real state of things,” the Russian defense minister blamed the commanders for poor organization.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: British Woman, 60, Wins Legal Round in Fight to Give Birth to Grandchild
item.description: A British appeals court handed a legal victory to a woman who wants to fulfill her daughter’s dying wish: to have her mother carry her baby and raise the child.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: The 5 Conservatives Vying to Become Britain’s Next Prime Minister
item.media:description: Theresa May, the British home secretary, is considered a candidate of continuity who is farther to the right of the party than David Cameron.
item.description: After Boris Johnson’s decision not to seek the leadership of the Conservative Party, these are the main contenders.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Taiwan-Owned Steel Factory Caused Toxic Spill, Vietnam Says
item.media:description: Squid traps piled up on the beach in the fishing village of Nhan Trach, Vietnam in May. A widespread fish kill virtually wiped out the squid population near the village and the traps were left unused. The Vietnamese government on Thursday said that the coastal disaster was caused by a Taiwan-owned steel factory that discharged a combination of chemicals, including cyanide, into the ocean.
item.media:credit: Richard C. Paddock/The New York Times
item.description: The government is seeking $500 million in compensation from Formosa Ha Tinh Steel for the spill that killed marine life and sickened many people.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Spanish Tax Authorities Investigate Google
item.media:description: Tax officials leaving Google’s offices in Madrid on Thursday.
item.description: Officials visited the technology giant’s offices in Madrid as part of their inquiry, broadening the scrutiny in Europe of how the company pays taxes.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT

item.title: News Analysis: Political Winner in Britain: Far Right, at Labour’s Expense
item.media:description: Jeremy Corbyn, the Labour Party leader, at a rally for him in London on Wednesday.
item.description: For the Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, losing seats in Parliament appears to be acceptable collateral damage in his long-term bid to reshape the party.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: U.S. Criticizes Myanmar Over Human Trafficking
item.media:description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and and Secretary of State John Kerry in Naypyidaw, Myanmar, in May.
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Nyein Chan Naing
item.description: In an annual report, the State Department lumped the fledgling democracy together with Iran, North Korea and Syria.
item.dc:creator: EMMARIE HUETTEMAN

item.title: 9 in Navy Disciplined Over Iran’s Capture of Sailors
item.media:description: A photograph released by the Revolutionary Guards in January showed detained American sailors at an undisclosed site in Iran.
item.media:credit: Sepahnews, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: A review of the incident, which occurred in January when two 50-foot Navy boats strayed into the waters near Farsi Island, found widespread mistakes.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Sinosphere: Beijing Police Officers Arrested in Environmentalist’s Death
item.description: An autopsy found that Lei Yang had died of suffocation after the police seized him, and two officers have been charged with “dereliction of duty.”
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Taliban Attack on Afghan Police Cadets Kills at Least 33
item.description: The double bombing on a police convoy was the second large-scale assault by the insurgents in Kabul in less than two weeks.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM and MOHAMAD FAHIM ABED

item.title: Turkey Says Airport Bombers Were From Kyrgyzstan, Russia and Uzbekistan
item.media:description: The uncle of Huseyin Tunc, a Turkish teacher killed in the Istanbul airport attack, carried his picture next to the coffin at a funeral in Istanbul on Thursday.
item.description: Officials have blamed the Islamic State for the attack in which dozens were killed, and raids and arrests have been carried out across the country.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU and RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: ‘Brexit’ Briefing: Boris Johnson Isn’t Running; Jeremy Corbyn Seeks Labour Revolution
item.media:description: Michael Gove, the justice secretary and one of the leaders of the “Leave” campaign, is a candidate to replace David Cameron as leader of the Conservative Party.
item.description: The Conservative Party (and by extension, Britain) is moving toward a new leader, while many people still don’t seem to know what “Brexit” is.
item.dc:creator: PRASHANT S. RAO

item.title: Roadside Attack Near Somali Capital Leaves at Least 14 Dead
item.media:description: The wreckage of a bus struck by a roadside bomb in Lafoole, near Somalia’s capital, Mogadishu, on Thursday.
item.description: There was no immediate claim of responsibility, but officials in the town of Lafoole said they believed the assault was the work of Islamist Shabab militants.
item.dc:creator: HUSSEIN MOHAMED

item.title: Boris Johnson Won’t Seek to Lead Britain, but Michael Gove Will
item.media:description: Michael Gove, who is seeking to succeed David Cameron as prime minister of Britain, said that Mr. Johnson “cannot provide the leadership or build the team for the task ahead.”
item.description: Mr. Johnson’s decision not to seek leadership of the Conservative Party came after Mr. Gove, a onetime ally, entered the contest.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Philippines’ New President, Rodrigo Duterte, Vows Tough Stance on Crime
item.description: He said in his inaugural speech that the harm of corruption and drugs justified his approach, and he dismissed concerns that such a campaign would abuse the rule of law.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Palestinian, 19, Stabs 13-Year-Old to Death in West Bank Settlement
item.media:description: The parents and a sister, left, of Hallel Yaffa Ariel, a 13-year-old killed in bed at her home, mourning at her funeral on Thursday.
item.description: The attack in the Kiryat Arba settlement was the latest in a series that began eight months ago; the assailant was shot and killed.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID and MYRA NOVECK

item.title: Who Else Can Sponsor a Refugee? The List Is Limited, for Now
item.media:description: Liz Stark, the grandmother in chief of a sponsor group in Canada, which allows citizens to band together in small groups and personally resettle — essentially adopt — a refugee family.
item.description: Canada has a longstanding policy allowing private sponsorship, but other countries are starting to experiment. Here’s how.
item.dc:creator: JODI KANTOR and CATRIN EINHORN
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Sinosphere: Beijing Rejects South China Sea Case Ahead of July 12 Ruling
item.media:description: People protesting territorial claims that Beijing has made in the South China Sea in front of the Chinese consular office in Makati City, south of Manila, in the Philippines, in June.
item.description: The case centers on an argument by the Philippines that China’s claims over much of the sea are illegal under a United Nations convention.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: How China Took Center Stage in Bitcoin’s Civil War
item.media:description: Racks of computers at a server farm mining Bitcoin and Ethereum.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: Through vast server farms and canny investments, Chinese companies have effectively centralized control over a currency designed to be borderless.
item.dc:creator: NATHANIEL POPPER

item.title: What in the World: How Do You Say ‘Welcome to Europe’ in Maltese? Check an Arabic Dictionary
item.description: About a third of the words, not to mention the language’s grammar, are derived from the Arabic that was spoken by Muslim settlers of the Mediterranean islands.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: What in the World: In China, Cheese Is Strange, but Pizza Is Hot
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tamara Shopsin / Love_Life / Boarding1Now / iStock.com
item.description: Dairy is not part of the mainstream Chinese diet, but one cheese seller’s prospects may improve as fast food, especially pizza, catches on.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: What in the World: France’s Latest American Import: Mermaid Schools
item.media:credit: Illustration by Lia Kantrowitz; Photos by Jung Hsuan, Valentyna Chukhlyebova/shutterstock
item.description: How would it feel to be Ariel from Disney’s “The Little Mermaid”? Girls who share that fantasy — and some women — are pulling on monofins and finding out.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Wassyl Slipak, Who Left Paris Opera for Ukraine War, Dies at 41
item.description: Mr. Slipak quit his baritone position in Paris to join nationalist fighters in his native Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Brazil’s Olympic Catastrophe
item.description: Can Rio pull off the Games with only weeks to go?
item.dc:creator: VANESSA BARBARA

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: In Venezuela, Political Prisoners as Pawns
item.media:description: People walk past a mural of President Nicolás Maduro in Caracas.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: The government of Venezuela is turning political prisoners into hostages by bartering them with other countries.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL LANSBERG-RODRÍGUEZ
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Erdogan in His Labyrinth
item.description: Turkey's descent into violence is of Erdogan's own creation. The airport attack was in many ways a bloodbath foretold.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
